clues.text: This "Godfather" author calls "The Fortunate Pilgrim", re-released in 1997, his best book
In 1917 he began "The Silmarillion", a history of Middle Earth before the Hobbits appeared
His first novel "The White Peacock" preceded "Sons and Lovers" by 2 years
Title of Kitty Kelley's 1997 bestseller about Britain's House of Windsor
"Perchance to Dream" with Philip Marlowe, is Robert B. Parker's sequel to this Raymond Chandler novel
The hypothetical primate some say could bridge the gap between man & his simian ancestors
You don't have to be a rocket scientist to know it's the command center for a manned space flight
A written message, perhaps a letter
In titles of films, it precedes "Mermaid", "Gambler", "Burning" & "Masala"
This synonym for "squandered" often describes a wastrel's wasted youth
Heloise suggests putting cheap sandwich bags over your hands before you pump this
These desktop items can be unbent to be used as hooks for your Christmas ornaments
After munching on moo goo gai pan, Heloise uses these as stakes for indoor potted plants
It's all downhill from here: Heloise recycles these masks by making them into little doggie sweaters
Ding-a-ling!  Heloise hangs these books on wire coat hangers & stores them in the closet
Rudolf Flesch said this was the system that should be used to teach kids to read -- sounds right
This diva began 1958 by walking out on opening night in Rome & ended it by being fired by the Met in NYC

The Omaha company that introduced the following product in 1954:
(TV Dinner)
In 1959 an ex-VP of Wurlitzer testified it was tough to sell these without an underworld connection

His resume:
May 31, 1958 -- made premier; Dec. 21, 1958 -- elected president; Jan. 5, 1959 -- "Time Man of the Year"
Anthony Quayle & this man were the 2 "A.Q."'s in "The Guns of Navarone"
He's been "Under Siege" twice as Navy SEAL turned cook Casey Ryback
Long before Warren Beatty, actor Ralph Byrd played this cop
In this 1973 film Woody Allen reads a 1990 New York Times headline, "Pope's Wife Gives Birth to Twins"
In this 1996 film D.A. Brad Pitt prosecutes 2 friends for a murder he's connected to

rounds.comments: (Alex: I will give you the clue & give you the words; you, like the contestants in that event, have to spell the words.)

clues.text:
1984:
Champ Daniel Greenblatt correctly spelled...

1982:
The champ was Molly Dieveney, & the final word was...

1989:
Scott Isaacs became the champ with...

1994:
Ned Andrews said a mouthful with...

1987:
Stephanie Petit really earned her win with...
Term for the commander of a "century", a group of about 100 soldiers
At the 31 B.C. Battle of Actium, this pair commanded the combined Roman-Egyptian fleets
Marcus Gavius Apicius wrote one of these in the first century; that's why Apician means gourmet
This "Younger" orator & letter writer whose "Elder" was killed by Vesuvius was governor of Bithynia
His second wife, Pompeia, was a granddaughter of Sulla who, like him, ruled Rome as a dictator
After parting ways with Burt Bacharach, he wrote "To All the Girls I've Loved Before"
He & Elton John met when both answered an ad placed by Liberty Records in 1967
In 1989 this singer-songwriter of "Alison" wrote the hit "Veronica" with Paul McCartney
This first great collaborator of Richard Rodgers wrote "My Funny Valentine" & "Isn't it Romantic?"
In 1992, a year after his death, his & Alan Menken's "Beauty and the Beast" won an Oscar as Best Song
He carries Badge 2211
At a banquet James Cagney told impressionist Frank Gorshin, "I never said, 'Mmm'", this
Cajun grain dish so-named because the chopped livers & gizzards in in made it appear "soiled"
After leaving the Eagles in 1982, Don Henley went gold with this first solo hit
In 1998 Michael Caine was one of these title sleazeballs
If a coin shows heads on 99 straight tosses, these are the odds on heads for the 100th toss
Ads for these state-run games, like Pick 6, often mention the jackpot, then give the odds on winning any prize
The odds against throwing a 6 with one die, or a Doors song that announced, "No one here gets out alive"
You can find the odds on your early death on these tables used by insurance companies
They're the odds of pulling 1 of the 4 aces from a full, shuffled deck
This German's attacks on the Roman Catholic church began the Reformation
This symbol of Judaism consists of 2 overlaid triangles
In Dec. 1945 the supreme commander of the Allied Powers in Japan disestablished this religion
Hymns in the Avesta are the only record, in his own words, of what this Persian prophet believed
Hindus believe that all gods are part of this one universal spirit
Add a new twist to your London vacation & visit the home at 48 Doughty St. where he wrote "Oliver Twist"
This Frenchman's mistress lived near Hauteville House , his home on Guernsey, making him less "miserable"
You'll find his birthplace "Far From the Madding Crowd" in Higher Bockhampton, near Dorchester
This American was living at Lamb House in Rye when he wrote "The Ambassadors" in 1903
The heart of this romantic poet is buried with his wife Mary at St. Peter's Church in Bournemouth

rounds.text: John Updike wrote "Rabbit, Run" partly in reaction to this more carefree novel that was published 3 years earlier
